benchmark_details.name: ScalingFilter
benchmark_details.overview: ScalingFilter is a novel approach that evaluates text quality based on the perplexity difference between two language models trained on the same data, eliminating the influence of reference datasets.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To propose a quality filtering method that assesses text quality without the biases introduced by reference datasets, thereby enhancing diversity and performance of language models.
purpose_and_intended_users.limitations: ScalingFilter relies on perplexity difference which may miss nuanced aspects of text quality like factual accuracy or bias. It requires significant computational resources for large datasets.

data.source: Five CommonCrawl dumps processed through the CCNet pipeline, yielding 500 GB of text data for quality filtering experiments.
data.annotation: Calculated quality factors based on perplexity differences using trained language models.

methodology.calculation: Metrics calculated by training a 1.3B model on filtered data and evaluating performance on several downstream tasks.
methodology.interpretation: Higher zero-shot performance and semantic diversity indicate better data quality and diversity.
methodology.baseline_results: Compared with existing quality filtering methods and achieved improvements in accuracy and semantic diversity.
methodology.validation: Results compared against baseline, random selection, and existing methods for performance verification.

harm: Potential for biased model outputs due to inherent biases in filtered data.
